On 15/01/2008, csabcsi.szucs <csaba.szucs@...> wrote:
>  Some weeks ago I read about a commercial testing tool that enables you
>  to write interface(GUI)-tests through JUnit tests, it sounds quite
>  strange (to use JUnit for end-to-end/integration testing)...

We use JUnit to run our end-to-end tests.  Our tests drive the client
GUI by controlling the mouse and keyboard, and also pretend to be
external systems by sending XML messages into the system via JMS.
With continual refactoring we have been able to keep the end-to-end
tests terse and expressive, hiding away all the asynchrony and
technical infrastructure.  It takes only a few minutes to write a new
end-to-end test.

For example:

public class SettledTradeTests extends EndToEndTestCase {
    public void
    testBuyAndSellForFullPositionAmountOnSameDayCausesRemovalOfTodoItem()
        throws Exception
    {
        gui.selectTab("Settled trades");
        gui.currentTodoList().hasRowCount(0);

        LocalDate sameDay = new  LocalDate(2007, 10, 18);

        when(aTradeIsSettled().withTradeId(123).with(anAllocation()
            .withSettlementDate(sameDay)
            .withActualSettledTradeAmount(USD(5))
            .withTradeType(BUY)));

        gui.currentTodoList().hasRowCount(1);

        when(aTradeIsSettled().withTradeId(456).with(anAllocation()
            .withSettlementDate(sameDay)
            .withActualSettledTradeAmount(USD(5))
            .withTradeType(SELL)));

        gui.currentTodoList().hasRowCount(0);
    }
    ...
}
